Vocabulary.mean: Yet is used to say something has not happened up to now.
Vocabulary.example: We can’t go out yet; we’re still eating.

Vocabulary.mean: An academy is a special type of school.
Vocabulary.example: There are many courses taught at the academy that I go to.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ancient, it is very old.
Vocabulary.example: I want to see the ancient buildings in Rome.

Vocabulary.mean: A board is a flat piece of wood.
Vocabulary.example: The sign was made of a few wooden boards.

Vocabulary.mean: A century is one hundred years.
Vocabulary.example: Our company is celebrating a century of business in London.

Vocabulary.mean: A clue is a fact or object that helps solve a mystery or crime.
Vocabulary.example: The detective found some clues on the sidewalk.

Vocabulary.mean: A concert is an event where you listen to people play music.
Vocabulary.example: I enjoyed the concert last night. The band was very good.

Vocabulary.mean: A county is the largest political division of a state in the US.
Vocabulary.example: He wanted to represent the citizens of his county.

Vocabulary.mean: A dictionary is a book that tells you what words mean.
Vocabulary.example: I use the dictionary to learn new words.

Vocabulary.mean: To exist is to be real.
Vocabulary.example: Do you really think that unicorns ever existed?

Vocabulary.mean: Flat describes something that is level and smooth with no curved parts
Vocabulary.example: My parents bought a new flat screen TV over the weekend.

Vocabulary.mean: A gentleman is a nice man.
Vocabulary.example: My grandfather is a kind and helpful gentleman.

Vocabulary.mean: Hidden means to be not easily noticed or too hard to find.
Vocabulary.example: The hidden camera recorded everything in the parking lot.

Vocabulary.mean: Maybe is used to show that something is possible or may be true.
Vocabulary.example: If I focus hard enough, maybe I can come up with the right answer.

Vocabulary.mean: An officer is a leader in the army.
Vocabulary.example: The soldiers followed the orders of the officer.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is original, it is the first one of that thing.
Vocabulary.example: This is the original painting of the Mona Lisa.

Vocabulary.mean: To pound something is to hit it many times with a lot of force.
Vocabulary.example: He pounded the nail with the hammer.

Vocabulary.mean: A process is the steps to take to do something.
Vocabulary.example: Making a cake is a long process.

Vocabulary.mean: To publish a book is to get it printed and ready to sell.
Vocabulary.example: That company publishes daily newspapers.

Vocabulary.mean: A theater is a building where you watch plays, shows, and movies.
Vocabulary.example: We went to the theater to see a play.

Vocabulary.mean: Wealth is a large amount of money.
Vocabulary.example: One of the most important things to some people is wealth.

Vocabulary.mean: To appreciate something is to understand its good qualities.
Vocabulary.example: I can appreciate the lovely scenery.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is available, it means you can get it.
Vocabulary.example: There were many seats available in the room.

Vocabulary.mean: To beat someone means to do better than they do.
Vocabulary.example: I managed to beat everyone in the race.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is bright, it shows a lot of light.
Vocabulary.example: The bright light from the explosion hurt my eyes.

Vocabulary.mean: To celebrate is to do something to show that an event is special.
Vocabulary.example: We all celebrated when we heard the great news.

Vocabulary.mean: To determine means to choose or make a decision.
Vocabulary.example: He tried to determine which one to eat first.

Vocabulary.mean: To disappear means to go away or not be seen.
Vocabulary.example: The top of the building is disappearing in the clouds.

Vocabulary.mean: If you talk about something else, you talk about something different.
Vocabulary.example: I wanted a bike for my birthday, but I got something else.

Vocabulary.mean: Fair describes treating someone in a way that is reasonable or right.
Vocabulary.example: He sold me his car for a fair price.

Vocabulary.mean: To flow is to move easily and continuously in one direction.
Vocabulary.example: The water flowed over the rocks and into the lake.

Vocabulary.mean: If you move forward, you move in the direction in front of you.
Vocabulary.example: When he saw his mother, the baby crawled forward to her.

Vocabulary.mean: A hill is a round area of land. It is higher than the land around it.
Vocabulary.example: The sun was rising above the green hills.

Vocabulary.mean: A level is a point on a scale that measures something.
Vocabulary.example: Please check the level of the temperature.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is lone, they are the only one of that kind.
Vocabulary.example: A lone man walked along the street.

Vocabulary.mean: A puddle is a pool of liquid on the ground.
Vocabulary.example: When the ice melted, it formed a puddle.

Vocabulary.mean: A response is the answer to a question.
Vocabulary.example: He asked if I was sad. My response was “No. ”

Vocabulary.mean: A season is a time of the year: spring, summer, fall or winter.
Vocabulary.example: Fall is a warm season, while winter is very cold.

Vocabulary.mean: A solution is a way to solve a problem.
Vocabulary.example: There are many problems. We need solutions!

Vocabulary.mean: To waste means to carelessly use something all up.
Vocabulary.example: Turn off the water so you don’t waste it.

Vocabulary.mean: You use whether when you must choose between two things.
Vocabulary.example: I could not decide whether to go left or right.

Vocabulary.mean: To argue is to angrily speak to someone because you do not agree.
Vocabulary.example: We argued about where to go for dinner.

Vocabulary.mean: To communicate is to give information by talking, writing, etc.
Vocabulary.example: I communicated with Paul about his new ideas.

Vocabulary.mean: A crowd is a large group of people.
Vocabulary.example: A large crowd had gathered on the street to see the accident.

Vocabulary.mean: To depend on someone or something is to need them.
Vocabulary.example: Children depend on their parents for many things.

Vocabulary.mean: A dish is a plate.
Vocabulary.example: She put a clean white dish on the table.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is empty, it does not have anything in it.
Vocabulary.example: My gas tank was almost empty, so I couldn’t drive my car very long.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is exact, it is just the right amount.
Vocabulary.example: Please use the exact amount of sugar for the cake.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is fresh, it is new.
Vocabulary.example: I just bought these oranges. They are very fresh.

Vocabulary.mean: To gather is to collect several things usually from different places.
Vocabulary.example: Sam gathered some flowers for his mother.

Vocabulary.mean: To indicate means to show, point or make something clear.
Vocabulary.example: He pointed to his eyes to indicate where he had hurt himself.

Vocabulary.mean: An item is a thing that you buy or sell.
Vocabulary.example: I have many items for school in my bag.

Vocabulary.mean: To offer is to present someone with something.
Vocabulary.example: He offered me the keys to his car.

Vocabulary.mean: The price of something is how much it costs.
Vocabulary.example: What is the price of this item?

Vocabulary.mean: A product is something that is made.
Vocabulary.example: My sister has many beauty products in her room.

Vocabulary.mean: Property is something that someone owns.
Vocabulary.example: The house is now my property.

Vocabulary.mean: To purchase something is to buy it.
Vocabulary.example: I recently purchased a new car.

Vocabulary.mean: To recommend something is to say that someone should do it.
Vocabulary.example: My doctor recommended that I get some exercise.

Vocabulary.mean: To select something is to choose it.
Vocabulary.example: I hope that I selected the right answers on the test.

Vocabulary.mean: A tool is something that helps you do a task.
Vocabulary.example: We used a tool to fix the window.

Vocabulary.mean: To treat is to act in a certain way toward someone.
Vocabulary.example: The cats treated the mouse very nicely.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is alive, they are not dead.
Vocabulary.example: My grandparents are still alive even though they are over 90.

Vocabulary.mean: A bone is a hard part of the body.
Vocabulary.example: I brought home a nice bone for my dog.

Vocabulary.mean: To bother is to make the effort to do something.
Vocabulary.example: No one bothered to wash the dishes today.

Vocabulary.mean: A captain is the person who leads a ship or airplane.
Vocabulary.example: The captain sailed his ship to Australia.

Vocabulary.mean: The conclusion of something is the final part of it.
Vocabulary.example: At the conclusion of the race, the spectators cheered for the winner

Vocabulary.mean: Doubt is a feeling of not being sure.
Vocabulary.example: I have doubt that the story is true.

Vocabulary.mean: To explore is to look for new places.
Vocabulary.example: He wants to explore the world and see new things.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is foreign, it is from a different country.
Vocabulary.example: Mexican food is a popular foreign food.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are glad, you are happy.
Vocabulary.example: I am glad you came to my party.

Vocabulary.mean: However means despite or not being influenced by something.
Vocabulary.example: She is a great cook. However, she never had professional lessons

Vocabulary.mean: Injustice is a lack of fairness or justice.
Vocabulary.example: Putting an innocent person in jail is an act of injustice.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is international, it involves more than one country.
Vocabulary.example: The United Nations is a powerful international organization.

Vocabulary.mean: A lawyer works with the law and represents people in court.
Vocabulary.example: The lawyer left the courthouse after the judge made her decision.

Vocabulary.mean: To mention something is to talk about it.
Vocabulary.example: The doctors mentioned the problems that the patient was having.

Vocabulary.mean: A policy is a rule.
Vocabulary.example: He told us that his policy was to put customers first.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is social, it is about many people in a community.
Vocabulary.example: People should come together and fix the world’s social problems.

Vocabulary.mean: A speech is something said to a group of people.
Vocabulary.example: She gave a speech to the class.

Vocabulary.mean: A staff is a group of people working together in a company.
Vocabulary.example: My dad has a staff of four people to help him at the office.

Vocabulary.mean: If you go toward something, you go closer to it.
Vocabulary.example: Santa walked toward my house with a special tree.

Vocabulary.mean: Wood is the thing that trees are made of.
Vocabulary.example: I put the pieces of wood in a pile.

Vocabulary.mean: To achieve something is to successfully do it after trying hard.
Vocabulary.example: I was happy that I could achieve my goal.

Vocabulary.mean: To advise someone is to tell them what to do.
Vocabulary.example: My mother often advises people about their money.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens already, it happens before a certain time.
Vocabulary.example: It is already time for the movie to start. Let’s go in.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is basic, it is very simple or easy.
Vocabulary.example: I learned some basic English skills in school today.

Vocabulary.mean: A bit is a small amount of something.
Vocabulary.example: I ate a bit of chocolate before I went to bed.

Vocabulary.mean: To consider something means to think about it.
Vocabulary.example: Pete didn’t like his job. He considered getting a new one.

Vocabulary.mean: To destroy means to damage something so badly that it cannot be used.
Vocabulary.example: The glass was destroyed.

Vocabulary.mean: To entertain someone is to do something that they enjoy.
Vocabulary.example: The clown entertained the kids at the party.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is extra, it is more than what is needed.
Vocabulary.example: The squirrel had extra nuts for the winter.

Vocabulary.mean: A goal is something you work toward.
Vocabulary.example: Her goal was to become a doctor.

Vocabulary.mean: To lie is to say or write something untrue to deceive someone.
Vocabulary.example: Whenever Pinocchio lied to his father, his nose grew.

Vocabulary.mean: Meat is food made of animals.
Vocabulary.example: This piece of meat I’m eating tastes very good.

Vocabulary.mean: An opinion is a thought about a person or a thing.
Vocabulary.example: Meg told me her opinion of my story. She said it was not funny.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is real, it actually exists.
Vocabulary.example: The handbag has a stamp on it, so it’s real.

Vocabulary.mean: To reflect is when a surface sends back light, heat, sound or an image.
Vocabulary.example: Her face was reflected on the smooth glass.

Vocabulary.mean: To regard someone or something is to think of them in a certain way.
Vocabulary.example: The boy regarded the girl as a good friend.

Vocabulary.mean: To serve someone is to give them food or drinks.
Vocabulary.example: He served us our drinks quickly.

Vocabulary.mean: A vegetable is a plant used as food.
Vocabulary.example: Carrots are my favorite vegetable.

Vocabulary.mean: A war is a big fight between two groups of people.
Vocabulary.example: Many young men died in the war.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is worth an amount of money, it costs that amount.
Vocabulary.example: Our house is worth a lot of money.

Vocabulary.mean: To appear is to seem.
Vocabulary.example: She appeared to be sad. She was crying.

Vocabulary.mean: The base is the bottom of something.
Vocabulary.example: The base of the table has three legs.

Vocabulary.mean: The brain is the organ in your head that lets you think.
Vocabulary.example: You must use your brain to solve the problem.

Vocabulary.mean: A career is a job that you do for a large part of your life.
Vocabulary.example: He was in the hospitality business for most of his career.

Vocabulary.mean: A clerk is a type of worker. Clerks in a store help customers.
Vocabulary.example: The clerk added up her bill for the groceries.

Vocabulary.mean: Effort is hard work or an attempt to do something.
Vocabulary.example: He always puts a lot of effort into his studies.

Vocabulary.mean: To enter a place is to go into it.
Vocabulary.example: Two guards greeted me as I entered the front door.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is excellent, it is very good.
Vocabulary.example: I got an excellent score on my school test.

Vocabulary.mean: A hero is a brave person who does things to help others.
Vocabulary.example: To children, the man in the blue and red costume was a real hero.

Vocabulary.mean: To hurry is to do something quickly.
Vocabulary.example: I hurried home on my bike.

Vocabulary.mean: To inform someone is to tell them about something.
Vocabulary.example: I called and informed her about my idea.

Vocabulary.mean: Later means after the present, expected, or usual time.
Vocabulary.example: She missed the train, so she’ll arrive a little later than expected.

Vocabulary.mean: To leave means to go away from someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: He packed his bag and was ready to leave for home.

Vocabulary.mean: To locate something is to find it.
Vocabulary.example: I could not locate my keys in the house.

Vocabulary.mean: A nurse is a person who helps sick people in the hospital.
Vocabulary.example: A nurse helped me get better.

Vocabulary.mean: An operation is when a doctor replaces or removes something in the body.
Vocabulary.example: The operation on my arm was a success.

Vocabulary.mean: Pain is the feeling that you have when you are hurt.
Vocabulary.example: His head was full of pain.

Vocabulary.mean: To refuse something is to say “no” to it.
Vocabulary.example: The dog refused to play with the cat.

Vocabulary.mean: Though is used when the second idea makes the first seem surprising.
Vocabulary.example: Though he was overweight, he liked to be active.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is various, there are many types of it.
Vocabulary.example: She owned shoes of various styles.

Vocabulary.mean: Actual means that something is real or true.
Vocabulary.example: This is the actual sword that the King owned, not a fake one.

Vocabulary.mean: To amaze someone is to surprise them very much.
Vocabulary.example: The news in the paper amazed Jack.

Vocabulary.mean: A charge is the price to pay for something.
Vocabulary.example: The charge for the shirts was $15.00.

Vocabulary.mean: To comfort someone means to make them feel better.
Vocabulary.example: I wanted to comfort my friend after I heard the bad news.

Vocabulary.mean: To contact someone is to speak or write to them.
Vocabulary.example: I contacted Sue about my party.

Vocabulary.mean: A customer is a person who buys something at a store.
Vocabulary.example: The customer put a few items in a bag.

Vocabulary.mean: To deliver something is to take it from one place to another.
Vocabulary.example: The man delivered Chinese food to my house.

Vocabulary.mean: To earn means to get money for the work you do.
Vocabulary.example: He earns his living as a chef in a great restaurant.

Vocabulary.mean: A gate is a type of door. Gates are usually made of metal or wood.
Vocabulary.example: We want to put up a wooden gate around our house.

Vocabulary.mean: To include something means to have it as part of a group.
Vocabulary.example: Does this meal include a soft drink?

Vocabulary.mean: To manage something means to control or be in charge of it.
Vocabulary.example: I had to manage the meeting myself.

Vocabulary.mean: A mystery is something that is difficult to understand or explain.
Vocabulary.example: The path on the map was a complete mystery to me.

Vocabulary.mean: To occur means to happen.
Vocabulary.example: When did the thunderstorm occur?

Vocabulary.mean: If A is the opposite of B, A is completely different from B.
Vocabulary.example: The opposite of black is white.

Vocabulary.mean: A plate is a flat round thing that you put food on.
Vocabulary.example: I put my plate down so I could put some food on it.

Vocabulary.mean: To receive something is to get it.
Vocabulary.example: I received a present on my birthday.

Vocabulary.mean: A reward is something given in exchange for good behavior or work.
Vocabulary.example: He was given a reward for his excellent performance.

Vocabulary.mean: To set something is to put it somewhere.
Vocabulary.example: Please set the dice down on the table.

Vocabulary.mean: To steal is to take something that is not yours.
Vocabulary.example: The men tried to steal money from the bank.

Vocabulary.mean: A thief is someone who quietly takes things that do not belong to them.
Vocabulary.example: A thief broke into our home and took my mother's jewelry.

Vocabulary.mean: To advance is to go forward.
Vocabulary.example: He advanced up the ladder slowly.

Vocabulary.mean: An athlete is a person who plays sports.
Vocabulary.example: Some athletes can play many sports very well.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is average, it is at a normal level.
Vocabulary.example: I’m not rich or poor; I’m average.

Vocabulary.mean: Your behavior is the way you act.
Vocabulary.example: Their behavior was good this semester. They didn’t cause trouble.

Vocabulary.mean: Behind means to be at the back of something.
Vocabulary.example: The little girl was hiding behind a tree.

Vocabulary.mean: A course is a class in school.
Vocabulary.example: I took a P.E. course in school this year.

Vocabulary.mean: To lower something is to make it go down.
Vocabulary.example: The chart shows how his production has lowered over the year.

Vocabulary.mean: To match is to be the same or similar.
Vocabulary.example: The two shoes matched. They looked the same.

Vocabulary.mean: A member is a person who is part of a group.
Vocabulary.example: Julie is the newest member of our team.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is mental, it has to do with your mind.
Vocabulary.example: I made a mental picture of the room.

Vocabulary.mean: A passenger is a person who rides in a car, train, or airplane.
Vocabulary.example: One passenger was standing in the subway train.

Vocabulary.mean: Your personality is what you are like and how you behave.
Vocabulary.example: John has a bad personality.

Vocabulary.mean: A poem is a short kind of writing.
Vocabulary.example: William Shakespeare wrote many poems.

Vocabulary.mean: A pole is a long thin stick made of wood or metal that supports things.
Vocabulary.example: The flag was hanging from the flag pole.

Vocabulary.mean: To remove something is to take it away.
Vocabulary.example: I removed the nail from the board.

Vocabulary.mean: Safety means to be the condition of being safe and free from danger.
Vocabulary.example: For his own safety, he was placed in a car seat.

Vocabulary.mean: To shoot is to fire something like a bullet at someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: The hunter raised his gun to shoot at the target.

Vocabulary.mean: To sound means to make a noise.
Vocabulary.example: The alarm clock sounded and woke us all up.

Vocabulary.mean: To swim is to move through water.
Vocabulary.example: I love to swim in the ocean.

Vocabulary.mean: A web is a home made by a spider.
Vocabulary.example: Mom cleaned the spider webs out of the garage.

Vocabulary.mean: A block is a solid piece of wood, stone or ice.
Vocabulary.example: I saw a block of ice on the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: To cheer is to give a loud shout of approval or encouragement.
Vocabulary.example: The crowd all cheered when the home team won.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is complex, it has many small parts. It is hard to understan
Vocabulary.example: A jigpuzzle can be complex because it has so many pieces.

Vocabulary.mean: A critic is someone who give their opinions about movies, books, plays
Vocabulary.example: The wine critic tasted the wine so he could give his opinion.

Vocabulary.mean: An event is something that happens, especially something important.
Vocabulary.example: Finishing high school was a major event in his life.

Vocabulary.mean: To exercise is to run or play sports so that you can be healthy.
Vocabulary.example: You should exercise every day.

Vocabulary.mean: If something fits, it is small enough orthe right size to go there.
Vocabulary.example: The colorful eggs fit into the box.

Vocabulary.mean: Friendship is the relationship between people who are friends.
Vocabulary.example: Michael and Lisa have a very strong friendship with each other.

Vocabulary.mean: A guide is someone who shows you where to go.
Vocabulary.example: We followed a guide at the park.

Vocabulary.mean: If there is a lack of something, there is not enough of it.
Vocabulary.example: His only problem is a lack of money.

Vocabulary.mean: A passage is a long area with walls that goes from one place to another
Vocabulary.example: The long passage led us to the other side of the field.

Vocabulary.mean: To perform is to do something in front of people who watch.
Vocabulary.example: He will perform a song for the class.

Vocabulary.mean: Pressure is what you apply to make someone do something.
Vocabulary.example: They put pressure on him to change his mind.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is probable, it is likely to happen.
Vocabulary.example: It is probable that you will get a good grade if you study for the test.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is public, it is meant for everyone to use.
Vocabulary.example: I went to the public park to play with my friends.

Vocabulary.mean: To strike someone or something is to hit them.
Vocabulary.example: She struck the other girl in the face.

Vocabulary.mean: To support something is to like it and help it be successful.
Vocabulary.example: Everyone at work supports the new plan.

Vocabulary.mean: A task is work that someone has to do.
Vocabulary.example: Who has the task of building the brick wall?

Vocabulary.mean: A term is a word for something.
Vocabulary.example: I often use the term “oops” when I make a mistake.

Vocabulary.mean: To unite is to get together to do something.
Vocabulary.example: If we unite, we can finish our project faster.

Vocabulary.mean: To associate means to connect something with a person or thing.
Vocabulary.example: Most people associate birthday parties with having fun.

Vocabulary.mean: The environment is the place where people work or live.
Vocabulary.example: Keeping our environment clean is important to our health.

Vocabulary.mean: A factory is a building where things are made or put together.
Vocabulary.example: We have only one factory in our town.

Vocabulary.mean: A feature is an important part of something.
Vocabulary.example: The cell phone has many features.

Vocabulary.mean: An instance is an example of something.
Vocabulary.example: I have never experienced an instance of hate. Have you?

Vocabulary.mean: To involve means to be actively taking part in something.
Vocabulary.example: The whole family was involved in playing the game.

Vocabulary.mean: Medicine is something you take to feel better or treat an illness.
Vocabulary.example: The doctor gave me medicine for my cold.

Vocabulary.mean: A mix is different things put together.
Vocabulary.example: The green mix we made in science class spilled onto the table.

Vocabulary.mean: To organize is to plan or get ready for an event.
Vocabulary.example: Make a list to help you organize the things you need.

Vocabulary.mean: A period is an amount of time when something happens.
Vocabulary.example: In one period in Europe, there were many knights.

Vocabulary.mean: If people populate an area, they live there.
Vocabulary.example: Billions of people populate the Earth.

Vocabulary.mean: To produce something is to make or grow it.
Vocabulary.example: This tree produces apples every year.

Vocabulary.mean: A range is a number or a set of similar things.
Vocabulary.example: I saw a range of cars to choose from.

Vocabulary.mean: To recognize something is to know it because you have seen it before.
Vocabulary.example: I recognized an old friend from many years ago.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is regular, it happens often and in equal amounts of time.
Vocabulary.example: Our regular lunch time is around noon.

Vocabulary.mean: A sign is a notice giving information, directions, a warning, etc.
Vocabulary.example: The sign indicated that today would be a bad day.

Vocabulary.mean: A tip is a pointed end of something.
Vocabulary.example: The tip of his pen was very sharp.

Vocabulary.mean: A tradition is something people have been doing for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: Marriage is a tradition all over the world.

Vocabulary.mean: Trash is waste material or unwanted or worthless things.
Vocabulary.example: Please take out the trash; it smells bad.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is wide, it is large from side to side.
Vocabulary.example: The door was as wide as my arms.

Vocabulary.mean: Advice is an opinion about what to do.
Vocabulary.example: I don’t know how to study for my exams. Can you give me some advice?

Vocabulary.mean: Along means to move from one part of a road, river, etc. to another.
Vocabulary.example: Walk along this tunnel for ten minutes, and you’ll see a door on the left.

Vocabulary.mean: Attention is the notice, thought, or consideration of someone.
Vocabulary.example: His work got the attention of two of his co-workers.

Vocabulary.mean: To attract means to make a person or thing come closer or be intereste
Vocabulary.example: The magnet attracted the metal.

Vocabulary.mean: To climb means to use your hands and feet to go up on something.
Vocabulary.example: The girls climbed to the top of the mountain.

Vocabulary.mean: To drop is to fall or allow something to fall.
Vocabulary.example: A small amount of water dropped from the bottle.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is final, it is the last part.
Vocabulary.example: In the final part of the film, the man and the woman got married.

Vocabulary.mean: Further is used to say something is from a distance or time.
Vocabulary.example: The escalator is further along than I thought.

Vocabulary.mean: To imply something is to suggest it without saying it.
Vocabulary.example: The man implied that he wanted the job, but he didn’t say so.

Vocabulary.mean: To maintain means to make something stay the same.
Vocabulary.example: The balls maintain constant movement.

Vocabulary.mean: You use neither to connect two negative statements.
Vocabulary.example: Neither the pass on the left nor the pass on the right will lead us home.

Vocabulary.mean: Otherwise means different or in another way.
Vocabulary.example: It’s good to stay active; otherwise, you’ll gain weight.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is physical, it is related to your body and not your mind.
Vocabulary.example: Biking is good for your physical health.

Vocabulary.mean: To prove something is to show that it is true.
Vocabulary.example: My teacher proved the answer on the board.

Vocabulary.mean: To react is to act in a certain way because of something that happened.
Vocabulary.example: James reacted badly to the news.

Vocabulary.mean: To ride something is to travel on it. You can ride an animal, a bike, etc.
Vocabulary.example: I will ride a rollerfor the first time today.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is situated somewhere, it is in that place.
Vocabulary.example: The white board is situated between the two men.

Vocabulary.mean: Society is people and the way that they live.
Vocabulary.example: Society expects people to be good and honest.

Vocabulary.mean: A standard is what people consider normal or good.
Vocabulary.example: This older model TV is below our store’s standards.

Vocabulary.mean: To suggest something means to give an idea or plan about it.
Vocabulary.example: He suggested that we go to see his boss.

Vocabulary.mean: Actually means in fact or really.
Vocabulary.example: My dad looks a little mean, but actually he’s very kind.

Vocabulary.mean: Bite is the act of using your teeth to cut and tear into something.
Vocabulary.example: The boy took a big bite out of his hamburger.

Vocabulary.mean: The coast is the land by an ocean.
Vocabulary.example: I stayed on the southern coast of Australia.

Vocabulary.mean: A deal is an agreement that you have with another person.
Vocabulary.example: I made a deal with the other company to give us some money.

Vocabulary.mean: The desert is an area of land without many plants or water.
Vocabulary.example: Not many plants grow in the desert.

Vocabulary.mean: An earthquake is a shaking movement of the ground.
Vocabulary.example: The building shook during the earthquake.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is effective, it works well.
Vocabulary.example: Swimming is an effective way to stay healthy.

Vocabulary.mean: To examine something is to look at it carefully.
Vocabulary.example: The doctor examined my eyes today.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is false, it is not correct.
Vocabulary.example: If you think the answer is false, press the red button.

Vocabulary.mean: A gift is something you give someone.
Vocabulary.example: Dave received many gifts for Christmas.

Vocabulary.mean: Hunger is the feeling that you get when you need to eat.
Vocabulary.example: After playing all day long, he was filled with hunger.

Vocabulary.mean: To imagine something is to think of it in your mind.
Vocabulary.example: Sally imagined herself winning lots of money.

Vocabulary.mean: A journey is a long trip.
Vocabulary.example: I went on a journey across the country with my parents.

Vocabulary.mean: A puzzle is something that is hard to understand.
Vocabulary.example: The question was a puzzle to him.

Vocabulary.mean: Quite is used to say that something is complete or very much.
Vocabulary.example: I think typing on a keyboard is quite easy.

Vocabulary.mean: Rather is used when you want to do one thing but not the other.
Vocabulary.example: I would rather have the red one than the blue one.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is specific, it is precise or exact.
Vocabulary.example: Please choose a specific place on the map.

Vocabulary.mean: A tour is a short trip in which you see many sights.
Vocabulary.example: I took a tour of Asia and Europe.

Vocabulary.mean: A trip is a journey to a certain place.
Vocabulary.example: Ken took a trip to the city yesterday.

Vocabulary.mean: If something has value, it is worth a lot of money.
Vocabulary.example: Matthew found a treasure of very high value.

Vocabulary.mean: A band is a group of people who play music.
Vocabulary.example: My brother is in a rock band.

Vocabulary.mean: Barely means by the smallest amount, almost not.
Vocabulary.example: I barely had enough money to pay for my bus ticket.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is boring, it is not fun.
Vocabulary.example: I think the Internet is boring.

Vocabulary.mean: To cancel means to decide that an event or a request will not happen.
Vocabulary.example: She cancelled the rest of her plans because of the rain.

Vocabulary.mean: A driveway is a short private road that leads to a person’s home.
Vocabulary.example: The long driveway led us to their new house.

Vocabulary.mean: Garbage is waste material like unwanted or spoiled food, bottles, paper, etc.
Vocabulary.example: The boy cleaned up the garbage around his house.

Vocabulary.mean: An instrument is something designed to do a certain task like music.
Vocabulary.example: My favorite musical instrument is the piano.

Vocabulary.mean: A list is a record of information printed with an item on each line.
Vocabulary.example: My mom makes a list of groceries to buy.

Vocabulary.mean: Magic is the power to do impossible things.
Vocabulary.example: The magician used magic to pull a rabbit out of his hat.

Vocabulary.mean: A message is a set of words that you send to someone.
Vocabulary.example: I left a message for you in the envelope.

Vocabulary.mean: To notice something is to see it for the first time.
Vocabulary.example: Did you notice the view?

Vocabulary.mean: To own something means to have it. That thing belongs to you.
Vocabulary.example: My grandfather owns that house.

Vocabulary.mean: To predict something is to say that it will happen.
Vocabulary.example: She predicted that I would get married next year.

Vocabulary.mean: A professor is a person who teaches in college.
Vocabulary.example: Mike’s science professor knows a lot about physics.

Vocabulary.mean: To rush is to go somewhere or do something very quickly.
Vocabulary.example: Nancy rushed to finish her homework.

Vocabulary.mean: A schedule is a plan that tells you when to do things.
Vocabulary.example: What is your class schedule for today?

Vocabulary.mean: To share something is to give some of it to another person.
Vocabulary.example: Jimmy shared his apple with me.

Vocabulary.mean: A stage is a place where actors or musicians act or sing.
Vocabulary.example: A large screen was on the stage.

Vocabulary.mean: A storm is very bad weather. There is a lot of rain or snow.
Vocabulary.example: Did that storm wake you up last night?

Vocabulary.mean: You use within to say that something is inside another thing.
Vocabulary.example: Within the box, there was a pizza.

Vocabulary.mean: To advertise is to tell people about something on TV, radio, etc.
Vocabulary.example: They used a rabbit to help them advertise their product.

Vocabulary.mean: To assign something to someone is to tell them to do it.
Vocabulary.example: I assigned the worker an important task.

Vocabulary.mean: An audience is a group of people who watch something together.
Vocabulary.example: There was a large audience at the game.

Vocabulary.mean: Breakfast is the first meal of the day.
Vocabulary.example: I eat breakfast at 8:00 every morning.

Vocabulary.mean: A competition is a contest to see who is the best at something.
Vocabulary.example: He won the running competition over the weekend.

Vocabulary.mean: If the weather is cool, it is a little bit cold.
Vocabulary.example: The weather is cool in the fall.

Vocabulary.mean: Ifyou gain something, you get more of it.
Vocabulary.example: I gained some weight over the summer.

Vocabulary.mean: Importance means the quality or condition of being needed or valued.
Vocabulary.example: VIPs are people of great importance.

Vocabulary.mean: Knowledge is information that you have about something.
Vocabulary.example: A music teacher should have good knowledge of music.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is major, it is big or important.
Vocabulary.example: I have a major problem. My boss wants me to redo my project!

Vocabulary.mean: Mean describes someone who is unkind or cruel.
Vocabulary.example: My cois a very mean person. He gets angry very quickly.

Vocabulary.mean: If you prefer something, you want it more than something else.
Vocabulary.example: I prefer to take the path that will lead me to a bright future.

Vocabulary.mean: A president is the leader of a country.
Vocabulary.example: The president of our country made an important announcement.

Vocabulary.mean: Progress is the act of getting closer to doing or finishing something.
Vocabulary.example: Our company made financial progress this year.

Vocabulary.mean: Respect is a good opinion of someone because they are good.
Vocabulary.example: I have great respect for firemen.

Vocabulary.mean: Ifyou are rich, you have a lot of money.
Vocabulary.example: He’s rich. He can buy anything he wants.

Vocabulary.mean: A skill is the knowledge and ability that allows you to do something well.
Vocabulary.example: A snowboarder must have the right skills to do well.

Vocabulary.mean: Somehow means in a way or by some means which is not known.
Vocabulary.example: He somehow had to find a way to reach the life preserver.

Vocabulary.mean: Strength is the physical power that you have.
Vocabulary.example: Exercising will increase your strength and give you more power.

Vocabulary.mean: To vote is to officially choose between two or more things.
Vocabulary.example: I voted for Billy to be our class president.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is above, it is at a higher level than something else.
Vocabulary.example: He straightened the sign that was above the crowd.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ahead of something else, it is in front of it.
Vocabulary.example: The blue car drove on ahead of us.

Vocabulary.mean: An amount is how much there is of something.
Vocabulary.example: Can I use my card to pay for the entire amount?

Vocabulary.mean: A belief is a strong feeling that something is correct or true.
Vocabulary.example: A preacher or priest should have a strong belief in God.

Vocabulary.mean: The center of something is the middle of it.
Vocabulary.example: The center of a dart board is the most important spot.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is common, it happens often or there is much of it.
Vocabulary.example: It is common for snow to fall in the winter.

Vocabulary.mean: To cost is to require expenditure or payment.
Vocabulary.example: These designer shoes cost more than the regular ones.

Vocabulary.mean: To demonstrate something is to show how it is done.
Vocabulary.example: She demonstrated her plan to her co-workers.

Vocabulary.mean: Different describes someone or something that is not the same as others.
Vocabulary.example: Each of my sisters has a different hair style from one another.

Vocabulary.mean: Evidence is a fact or thing that you use to prove something.
Vocabulary.example: He used the pictures as evidence that UFOs are real.

Vocabulary.mean: Honesty means the quality of being truthful or honest.
Vocabulary.example: A courtroom should be a place of honesty.

Vocabulary.mean: An idiom is a phrase with a meaning different from its words.
Vocabulary.example: The idiom “when pigs fly” means that something will never happen.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is independent, it is not controlled by something else.
Vocabulary.example: She chose to live an independent life in the country.

Vocabulary.mean: Inside means the inner part, space or side of something.
Vocabulary.example: The inside of the box was empty.

Vocabulary.mean: A master is a person who is very good at something.
Vocabulary.example: My brother is a master of taekwondo.

Vocabulary.mean: A memory is something you remember.
Vocabulary.example: The memory of my first time in the city will always be the best.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is proper, it is right.
Vocabulary.example: It is not proper to throw your garbage on the road.

Vocabulary.mean: To scan something is to look at it very carefully.
Vocabulary.example: You must scan each person closely.

Vocabulary.mean: A section is a part of something larger.
Vocabulary.example: The green section of the graph is the most important part.

Vocabulary.mean: The sake of something is the reason for doing it.
Vocabulary.example: The parents worked hard for their children’s sake.
